content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, Given a struct `FloatWithUnits` with fields `value` and `unit` (make sure to define it!), write a `show` method for it that will concatenate the value and unit with a space like this "1.8 meters".

In Julia, you can define a custom `show` method for your struct by simply defining a function called `show` in your struct's module. Below is an example of how you might do it:

```julia
module MyModule

struct FloatWithUnits
    value::Float64
    unit::String
end

function show(io::IO, fwu::FloatWithUnits)
    print(io, "$(fwu.value) $(fwu.unit)")
end

end # module
```
In the example above, `MyModule` is the name of your module where you defined the `FloatWithUnits` struct and the `show` method. You can use this module in a script by calling `using MyModule`. Then when you print an object of type `FloatWithUnits`, it will be printed with the value and unit separated by a space, like "1.8 meters".
